title: Nature's mood rings: How chameleons really change color

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why chameleons change color?

options.label: A
options.text: To blend in with their environment

options.label: B
options.text: To regulate their body temperature

options.label: C
options.text: To make a statement or express their emotions

options.label: D
options.text: To communicate with other chameleons

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the cells that contain tiny, nano-scale salt crystals in a chameleon's skin?

options.label: A
options.text: Melanocytes

options.label: B
options.text: Iridophores

options.label: C
options.text: Chromatophores

options.label: D
options.text: Epithelial cells

multiple-choice.question: How do chameleons change the color of their skin?

options.label: A
options.text: By spreading out pigments in their cells

options.label: B
options.text: By stretching or contracting the lattice of salt crystals in their skin

options.label: C
options.text: By changing the shape of their skin cells

options.label: D
options.text: By secreting different hormones

options.label: C
options.text: Blue jay butterfly

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Why does February only have 28 days?

multiple-choice.question: Why did the Romans need a calendar?

options.label: A
options.text: To keep track of their increasing number of festivals and celebrations.

options.label: B
options.text: To organize their military ceremonies and events.

options.label: C
options.text: To accurately calculate the time between two solar equinoxes or solstices.

options.label: D
options.text: To predict the weather.

multiple-choice.question: What was the problem with the original Roman calendar?

options.label: A
options.text: It had too many days in a year.

options.label: B
options.text: It had too few days in a year.

options.label: C
options.text: It didn't account for leap years.

options.label: D
options.text: It was based on the solar calendar.

multiple-choice.question: Why did Numa Pompilius remove a day from all the even-numbered months?

options.label: A
options.text: Because he wanted to make the calendar more accurate.

options.label: B
options.text: Because even numbers were considered bad luck in Ancient Rome.

options.label: C
options.text: Because he wanted to make the calendar more complicated.

options.label: D
options.text: Because he wanted to honor the gods.

multiple-choice.question: What was the purpose of the leap month added to the Roman calendar?

options.label: A
options.text: To account for the extra days in a year.

options.label: B
options.text: To honor the gods.

options.label: C
options.text: To extend the terms of politicians.

options.label: D
options.text: To confuse the population.

multiple-choice.question: Who reformed the Roman calendar to create the solar calendar used today?

options.label: A
options.text: Romulus.

options.label: B
options.text: Numa Pompilius.

options.label: C
options.text: Julius Caesar.

options.label: D
options.text: Pope Gregory.

title: How did the deepest part of the ocean get so polluted?

multiple-choice.question: What is the approximate depth of the Mariana Trench, the deepest known part of the ocean?

options.label: A
options.text: 10,000 feet

options.label: B
options.text: 20,000 feet

options.label: C
options.text: 36,000 feet

options.label: D
options.text: 50,000 feet

multiple-choice.question: What type of pollution was found in the fatty tissue of amphipods living in the deepest oceanic trenches?

options.label: A
options.text: Heavy metals

options.label: B
options.text: Persistent organic pollutants (POPs)

options.label: C
options.text: Radioactive waste

options.label: D
options.text: Microplastics

multiple-choice.question: According to the researchers, what may be the source of the pollution found in the Mariana Trench?

options.label: A
options.text: The Great Pacific Garbage Patch

options.label: B
options.text: Carrion-falls from polluted waters

options.label: C
options.text: Industrial waste dumping

options.label: D
options.text: Both A and B

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of ocean pollution on marine life?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased oxygen levels

options.label: B
options.text: Improved reproductive health

options.label: C
options.text: Mass death and reproductive issues

options.label: D
options.text: No impact

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of persistent organic pollutants (POPs) entering the food chain?

options.label: A
options.text: They are broken down by organic organisms

options.label: B
options.text: They are removed from the environment

options.label: C
options.text: They contaminate the food supply and potentially harm humans

options.label: D
options.text: They have no impact on the food chain

title: The science of laziness

options.label: A
options.text: Serotonin system

options.label: B
options.text: Endorphin system

options.label: C
options.text: Dopamine system

options.label: D
options.text: Adrenaline system

options.label: A
options.text: They ran on their wheels 25% less often than the other group

options.label: B
options.text: They ran on their wheels 50% more often than the other group

options.label: C
options.text: They ran on their wheels 75% more often than the other group

options.label: D
options.text: They ran on their wheels the same amount as the other group

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential genetic link to physical laziness?

options.label: A
options.text: A mutation in a gene responsible for regulating sleep patterns

options.label: B
options.text: A mutation in a gene responsible for regulating activity levels

options.label: C
options.text: A mutation in a gene responsible for regulating appetite

options.label: D
options.text: A mutation in a gene responsible for regulating mood

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of depriving the brains of the running mice of physical activity?

options.label: A
options.text: Their brains react similarly to a rodent that has been given a reward

options.label: B
options.text: Their brains react similarly to a rodent that has been given a sedative

options.label: C
options.text: Their brains react similarly to a drug-addicted rodent that has been deprived of cocaine or nicotine

options.label: D
options.text: Their brains react similarly to a rodent that has been given a stimulant

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what can help individuals overcome their genetic predisposition to laziness?

options.label: A
options.text: Medication

options.label: B
options.text: Surgery

options.label: C
options.text: Environmental and mental factors, such as motivation and knowledge

options.label: D

title: Why does everyone hate pigeons?

multiple-choice.question: Why did Charles Darwin choose pigeons as his first example in Chapter 1 of "On the Origin of Species"?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they were the most abundant species at the time.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they were able to fly faster than other birds.

options.label: C
options.text: Because underneath their variations, they are just one species.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they were the easiest to study.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about a pigeon's eyes?

options.label: A
options.text: They have three color receptors.

options.label: B
options.text: They have five color receptors.

options.label: C
options.text: They can only see in black and white.

options.label: D
options.text: They are very small.

multiple-choice.question: What was psychologist B.F. Skinner trying to create during WW II using pigeons?

options.label: A
options.text: A new form of communication.

options.label: B
options.text: Explosive missiles piloted by kamikaze pigeons.

options.label: C
options.text: A new form of transportation.

options.label: D
options.text: A new type of food source.

multiple-choice.question: How do pigeons navigate to find their way home?

options.label: A
options.text: Using only visual maps.

options.label: B
options.text: Using only the Earth's magnetic field.

options.label: C
options.text: Using a combination of visual maps, Earth's magnetic field, the angle of the sun, and smells.

options.label: D
options.text: Using only their sense of smell.

multiple-choice.question: Why are pigeons good at delivering messages?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are very fast flyers.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are tightly bonded to their home and have a strong instinct to return.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are very intelligent birds.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are very social birds.

title: How do pelicans survive their death-defying dives?

multiple-choice.question: How do brown pelicans protect their delicate bones while diving into the water at high speeds?

options.label: A
options.text: They fold their wings and tuck their heads.

options.label: B
options.text: They shoot their wings back and tense powerful muscles around their spine.

options.label: C
options.text: They inflate their air sacs to cushion the impact.

options.label: D
options.text: They use their gular pouch as a parachute.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the gular pouch in a brown pelican?

options.label: A
options.text: To store food for later consumption.

options.label: B
options.text: To slow the bird down during dives and act as a fishing net.

options.label: C
options.text: To regulate the bird's body temperature.

options.label: D
options.text: To attract mates during breeding season.

multiple-choice.question: How do brown pelicans manage to float after hitting the water at high speeds?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a thick layer of fat that keeps them buoyant.

options.label: B
options.text: They have a special network of extra air sacs under their skin and in their bones.

options.label: C
options.text: They use their powerful muscles to swim back up to the surface.

options.label: D
options.text: They inflate their gular pouch to stay afloat.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the way a brown pelican's jaw opens?

options.label: A
options.text: It can only open up and down.

options.label: B
options.text: It can only open sideways.

options.label: C
options.text: It can open both up and down and sideways.

options.label: D
options.text: It cannot open at all.

multiple-choice.question: How long have brown pelicans been using their unique diving and fishing techniques?

options.label: A
options.text: For thousands of years.

options.label: B
options.text: For tens of thousands of years.

options.label: C
options.text: For millions of years.

options.label: D
options.text: For tens of millions of years.

title: Why do we wrinkle when wet?

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the skin when it is immersed in water for a prolonged period of time?

options.label: A
options.text: The skin becomes smooth and soft.

options.label: B
options.text: The skin remains unchanged.

options.label: C
options.text: The skin wrinkles and becomes pruney.

options.label: D
options.text: The skin becomes dry and cracked.

multiple-choice.question: What was the initial theory behind the wrinkling of skin when immersed in water?

options.label: A
options.text: It was caused by the nervous system's response to moisture.

options.label: B
options.text: It was caused by the expansion of skin tissue.

options.label: C
options.text: It was caused by a type of osmosis, where water passes into the dry outer layer of skin.

options.label: D
options.text: It was caused by the constriction of blood vessels.

multiple-choice.question: What did the 2013 study on wrinkly skin find?

options.label: A
options.text: That wrinkly skin had no effect on grip.

options.label: B
options.text: That wrinkly skin made it harder to pick up objects.

options.label: C
options.text: That wrinkly skin helped channel water away, making it easier to pick up wet objects.

options.label: D
options.text: That wrinkly skin only helped with dry objects.

multiple-choice.question: Why might it be advantageous for skin to become wrinkly in wet conditions?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes the skin more sensitive.

options.label: B
options.text: It makes the skin less sensitive.

options.label: C
options.text: It gives the skin a better grip on wet objects.

options.label: D
options.text: It makes the skin more prone to dryness.

multiple-choice.question: Why might it not be advantageous for skin to be wrinkly all the time?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it would make the skin too sensitive.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it would make the skin less sensitive.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it would make the skin more prone to dryness.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it would make the skin more prone to wrinkles.

title: The history of manners

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason for the development of manners in human society?

options.label: A
options.text: To hide one's true nature and intentions

options.label: B
options.text: To show respect and kindness towards others

options.label: C
options.text: To establish social hierarchy and status

options.label: D
options.text: To follow traditional customs and norms

options.text: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Catherine de' Medici

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It was a popular drinking vessel among the aristocracy

title: Why don't we throw trash in volcanoes?

multiple-choice.question: Why is sending trash to volcanoes to burn it not a viable solution?

options.label: A
options.text: Because volcanoes are too far away from cities.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it would be expensive and could release toxic fumes.

options.label: C
options.text: Because volcanoes are not hot enough to burn trash.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it would create new landforms.

multiple-choice.question: What is one problem with drilling into a volcano's magma chamber to dispose of trash?

options.label: A
options.text: It would be too expensive.

options.label: B
options.text: It would release toxic gases.

options.label: C
options.text: It could trigger a violent eruption.

options.label: D
options.text: It would create a new volcano.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when organic matter like food scraps hits lava?

options.label: A
options.text: It burns slowly and steadily.

options.label: B
options.text: It melts and becomes part of the lava.

options.label: C
options.text: It explodes due to the rapid boiling of water.

options.label: D
options.text: It disappears instantly.

multiple-choice.question: Why is burning trash in volcanoes not a good idea, even if it seems like a convenient solution?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it would create jobs for people to transport trash to volcanoes.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it would reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it could release toxic fumes and create explosive reactions.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it would be a cheap solution.

options.label: A
options.text: Burning it in volcanoes.

options.label: B
options.text: Burying it in landfills.

options.label: C
options.text: Using controlled incineration plants to generate electricity.

options.label: D
options.text: Recycling and reducing waste.

options.label: C

options.text: Because they were originally painted white

options.label: B

title: Why parrots can talk like humans

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the human voice box (larynx) and the bird voice box (syrinx)?

options.label: A
options.text: The larynx is located at the bottom of the trachea, while the syrinx is located at the top.

options.label: B
options.text: The larynx contains vocal folds that vibrate to produce sound, while the syrinx uses muscles to shape and produce sound.

options.label: C
options.text: The larynx is used for breathing, while the syrinx is used for singing.

options.label: D
options.text: The larynx is only found in humans, while the syrinx is only found in birds.

multiple-choice.question: How do parrots replicate plosive sounds, such as the "p" sound in "pocket", without having lips?

options.label: A
options.text: They use their tongue to block the airflow.

options.label: B
options.text: They use their beak to shape the sound.

options.label: C
options.text: They use esophageal speech, which is like burping from within the trachea.

options.label: D
options.text: They are unable to replicate plosive sounds.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the way parrots use their tongues to shape sound?

options.label: A
options.text: They only use their tongues to shape vowels.

options.label: B
options.text: They only use their tongues to shape consonants.

options.label: C
options.text: They move their tongues forward and backward to alter the sound.

options.label: D
options.text: They do not use their tongues to shape sound at all.

multiple-choice.question: Why do parrots in captivity often mimic human speech?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are trying to communicate with their flock.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are trying to learn a new language.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they form a social bond with their human caregivers and want to communicate with them.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are bored and need something to do.

options.label: A
options.text: Lyrebird

options.label: B
options.text: Cardinal

options.label: C
options.text: Parrot

options.label: D
options.text: Mockingbird

title: Do we own the land?

title: Who owns Antarctica?

multiple-choice.question: Who owns Antarctica?

options.label: A
options.text: No one country owns it, but it is managed by the United Nations.

options.label: B
options.text: It is the common heritage of mankind, belonging to no one and everyone.

options.label: C
options.text: The United States and the Soviet Union have joint ownership.

options.label: D
options.text: The countries that have made claims on the continent own their respective territories.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main purpose of the Antarctic Treaty signed in 1959?

options.label: A
options.text: To establish Antarctica as a nature preserve and scientific research haven.

options.label: B
options.text: To divide the continent among the signatory countries.

options.label: C
options.text: To allow for military and mining activities on the continent.

options.label: D
options.text: To establish a permanent human settlement on Antarctica.

multiple-choice.question: Why did countries not give up their claims on Antarctica when signing the treaty?

options.label: A
options.text: They wanted to maintain their territorial claims for future reference.

options.label: B
options.text: They were not willing to compromise on the issue.

options.label: C
options.text: The treaty did not require them to do so.

options.label: D
options.text: They were concerned about the environmental impact of human activity on the continent.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the "blank spot" on maps of Antarctica?

options.label: A
options.text: It represents a disputed territory between two or more countries.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a nature reserve that is off-limits to human activity.

options.label: C
options.text: It is the largest territory unclaimed on Earth by any nation.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a region with significant mineral deposits.

multiple-choice.question: What is set to be reviewed in the 2040s, potentially changing the dynamics of Antarctica's ownership?

options.label: A
options.text: The Antarctic Treaty itself.

options.label: B
options.text: The mining ban on the continent.

options.label: C
options.text: The environmental regulations for human activity on Antarctica.

options.label: D
options.text: The territorial claims made by countries.
